newsitem.title: ITALY: Versace sees fashion's future in gentlemen past.
newsitem.headline: Versace sees fashion's future in gentlemen past.

text.p: Italian fashion designer Gianni Versace turned back the clock in his vision of style into the new millenium on Sunday while Valentino gilded classic male elegance with a touch of glitz at the start of the Milan shows.
Versace, unveiling his 1997/98 autumn/winter Gianni Versace, Versus and Istante collections, married end-of-the-century taste back to start-of-the-century elegance of the English gentleman.
High-buttoned, neat-collared jackets and knee-length frock coats were finished with stylish contrasting collars in alternative materials like velvet.
Tweeds, Prince of Wales checks and the occasional vibrant red tartan cloth for single and double-breasted jackets and coats cut a predominantly narrow, columnlike profile.
"My interpretation of fashion tastes for the end of the century is far from all trends...dominated by the desire for extreme individuality," Versace said.
The designer aimed for a classic look he called "Baroque minimalism" in his top line Versace collection, using a palette of sophisticated dark blues, forest green and hints of mustard.
Hints of futurism crept in with a pristine white turtleneck pullover matched with white pants and a long white coat.

For the young man about town came torso-tight long-sleeved tops in trademark Versace purple, yellow and red, some with a bold motif and reminiscent of shirts worn by galaxy trotters in the popular U.S. film and television series Star Trek.

Valentino Man combined classic elegance of double-breasted suits and knee or calf length coats with a splash of opulence from gold embroidered ties and cardigans trimmed with a generous swathe of rabbit fur at the collar.

For conservative dressers came chalk stripe flannels and the subtle grace of double-breasted wool suits in navy with double vents and two flapped pockets as well as turtleneck pullovers in charcoal grey, olive green and camel.
But Valentino threw in some spice by setting dusky blues and amethyst off against burgundy trousers and placing pale, creamy see-through knits over pepper red shirts.

"The perfection of luxury is never ostentatious but rather a very strong yet discreet appeal of shades stolen from precious stones, from... powder and milk, from tapestries and damask," Valetino said.

For casual outdoors came a mint-coloured short sheepskin coat with a neat Nehru collar worn over a brick-coloured cashmere turtleneck and herringbone trousers, and a short black velvet double breasted coat with alternate panels of diagonal ribbing and horizontal ribbing.
Designers parading their collections on Monday include Krizia, fashion duo Dolce & Gabbana and Gianfranco Ferre as well as Britain's Vivienne Westwood.
The shows run until Thursday, when top designer Giorgio Armani provides the finale to the five-day event.
